tier.item: Kuda has alethic particularities which render it difficult to strike a clear contrast with kyan. C.f. Cinque
It would be inaccurate to conclude that mos cannot give rise to an interpretation where the speaker's opinion is
involved. This ambiguous nature is also attested with dwe for some speakers of Haitian Creole (c.f. Leblanc

tier.item: (5) Haitian CF (Lefebvre 1998:161; cited from Déchaine & Manfredi 1994)
Kenya Pidgin Swahili, for example, does not exhibit any traces of creolization, yet it has developed a
number of new functional categories (see Heine 1991).
For example, Saramaccan, which we classify here as an English-lexified creole could also be classified
As we will see below, however, the term intensifier, or its equivalents identifier, emphatic reflexive,
etc., raises problems since it simulatenously refers to a number of contrastive uses of one and the same
